messages.messageText: how to make .gitignore respect cli command
messages.responseText:
To make the `.gitignore` file respect a CLI command, you typically don't modify the `.gitignore` file itself. Instead, you can use Git commands to temporarily ignore or include files that are otherwise controlled by `.gitignore`. Here are a few approaches you can use:

1. To temporarily ignore changes to a tracked file:

```
git update-index --assume-unchanged <file>
```

To undo this:

```
git update-index --no-assume-unchanged <file>
```

2. To force add a file that's ignored:

```
git add -f <file>
```

3. To check why a file is being ignored:

```
git check-ignore -v <file>
```

4. To temporarily allow ignored files in your next commit:

```
git add -A
git commit -m "Your message" --no-verify
```

These commands allow you to override `.gitignore` behavior from the command line without modifying the `.gitignore` file itself. Choose the appropriate command based on your specific needs.

I am getting Refused to execute inline event handler because it violates the following Content Security Policy directive: "script-src 'nonce-OvuNcaWrdZnX6vCcETCLuwaE13nDCW24' 'self' https://*.vscode-cdn.net". Either the 'unsafe-inline' keyword, a hash ('sha256-...'), or a nonce ('nonce-...') is required to enable inline execution. Note that hashes do not apply to event handlers, style attributes and javascript: navigations unless the 'unsafe-hashes' keyword is present.
